I think it's necessary to split the review for this game into two parts: the story part (as most people do, in fact, play games for the story) and the gameplay part. I think both of them are great, as far as japanese SRPGs go.

The story revolves around a young girl named Marona who's lost her parents and has a spirit guardian named Ash filling the role of her older brother and sort of mentor/protector. Ash is a ghost whom only Marona can see, and the only being who cares and looks out for her. Most of the people Marona encounters consider her an abomination for seeing ghosts and talking to them. She also gets incredibly brutal and unfair treatment because she's seen by everyone as an orphan girl with a freaky and dangerous power. Despite that, she never gives up. No matter how harsh the people treat her, how difficult and unfair her circumstances are, she endures them all, and when you play the game, it feels incredibly genuine and not just because Marona is "such a nice and friendly girl!". Her willingness to help those who are treated even less fairly than she is, those who are struggling, is genuine and heart-warming, and it's Marona's own way to cope with all the harsh treatment and loss she has to endure. It's a tale of a very selfless girl whose kindness knows no bounds, and perhaps her kindness would inspire the players in turn. 

The gameplay relies heavily on grind, which is a staple for Disgaea series and its spinoffs. However, the gameplay takes its own unique turn with Marona's abilities to summon spirits, or "phantoms" who fight alongside her, as well as picking up stuff scattered around the stages to use as weapons, alongside the usual weapon choice like swords, spears and staffs. Even a measly rock and a random weed have an incredibly power lying dormant in them! Which is, of course, pretty awesome. Leveling up weapons also offers the player an opportunity to completely break the game because you're free to make them as overpowered as you desire. The phantoms can only be summoned for a limited number of turns, and Marona can only summon a limited amound of those from her roster, so you have to plan out many of the more difficult fights ahead (or keep replaying till you get them right). The stages also offer your units opportunity to more or less free roam, which is slightly more confusing when it comes to positioning compared to grid and more predictable and fixed positioning.
Difficulty level expects you to grind a lot and can get pretty brutal if you don't commit enough to grind, and straight out impossible if you choose to neglect grinding altogether. If you don't enjoy grinding, this isn't the game for you.

The soundtrack is incredibly nice and has an easy-going, yet somewhat somber and melancholic feeling to it; it's never about pure carefree joy, which further enhances the general direction of the story and Marona's character. It also makes even the sloggiest of the stages and the grindiest of grinds a better experience. 
The graphics, however... Well, the 3D part of the stages looks ok, as well as the backgrounds; unfortunately, pixel sprites are blurry and feel very out of place because of said blurriness. The PC version is pretty much an emulation of the PS2 game, which PB originally was, and it's definitely not meant to be viewed on modern HD monitors. Which is a shame, because the sprite work is really detailed and varied, but it turns out to be such a mess on the actual screen.

Overall, the game is really good if you're willing to commit effort to grind. The only downside I can really point out is the blurry pixel sprites, which is a glaring shame on a game that's otherwise pretty much flawless.

If you're familiar with Nippon Ichi's other Strategy RPGs, most popularly Disgaea, then you should already have some idea of what to expect here.  The game does feature several fundamental differences, however, the major ones being that the game isn't grid based and instead lets you traverse the map freely and that the introduction of the "Confine" system means that rather than summoning characters permanently from a base you instead summon them using items on the map via the main character, Marona.

Each of these things come with their own pros and cons.  Having your phantoms on a timer seems annoying but it adds another layer of strategy to the game and whether that's better or worse for you really depends on how you vary your regalia.  As for the lack of a grid, this freedom can lead to some odd behavior and questionable AI logic at times but it clearly allowed them to make gameplay that was more dynamic than something you would get out of a Disgaea or a Soul Nomad, largely thanks to terrain effects and physics.

As far as the story is concerned, starting out you have two options: [b]New Game[/b] and [b]Another Marona[/b].  [I]Another Marona[/I] is a standalone story that was introduced in the game's Wii port, [I]Phantom Brave: We Meet Again[/I], and because it includes characters and allusions to the main story, it's best to save this for after having beaten the game at least once (it can also be accessed through the New Game+ option after beating the game, though it's best played starting at level one).

Starting a new game, you'll run into an unskippable tutorial and unskippable cutscenes.  Don't let these leave too big of a negative impression on you because in general the game's cutscenes are short and all of them past the first are skippable, so it's mostly replay-friendly.  You play as a chroma (basically someone who deals in various types of odd jobs) named Marona, an orphan who can see and summon phantoms.  While some would consider this a gift, most see the girl as a witch who is possessed by phantoms and is filled with malintent.  This couldn't be farther from the truth, of course, as Marona is about as pure as her age implies and all she really wants is to help others.  While a character and setup like this could easily be annoying, it's played to pretty great effect as Marona is torn down over and over again before it looks like she has any chance of standing on her own, and this is made better by seeing how the mail that she gets reacts to current events (and the mail is probably some of the darkest content in this game, which says a lot more than it sounds like).

Much like Disgaea, Phantom Brave is a level-based Strategy RPG that takes place over a series of maps.  Put simply, if you like Disgaea's gameplay, you'll like this after you get used to it.  And then you'll like it more when you realize that each different type of item that can be found on a map has its own skill set.  Then you'll like it more when you realize you can use the Fusionist to combine items together to give them really interesting skills and stat buffs.  And then you'll like it even [B]more[/B] when you realize just how fun and satisfying giving custom titles to your characters and their items can be.  

Phantom Brave's gameplay is by no means perfect and has a fair few imperfections, some of the more major ones I mentioned above, but the emphasis on customization and use of the environment as well as generally interesting map designs just makes it one hell of a fun romp that isn't much like any other game NIS has put out, even its spiritual successor, Makai Kingdom.

As for the graphics, they're ugly as sin.  Absolutely ugly as sin.  Normally, I would just say they're dated, because that's what they are.  Normally I wouldn't be so hard on the game.  But normally a game like this that didn't even have all that big of a following doesn't get 3 subsequent ports over 10 years on variably stronger hardware without anyone doing anything about the fact that the game looks like it was made for the PS1 after the PS2 had already been out for 4 goddamn years.  Thankfully, the UI fonts and textures have been brought up to date, and though that does make the sprites feel even more uncanny, it's at least nice to see that some effort was made.

And finally, the music.  It's always amazing to me how Tenpei Sato manages to make his games feel unique.  If you blindfolded a NIS fan and played tracks from several different NIS developed games, they'd somewhat easily be able to tell you what was from Rhapsody, what was from Disgaea, and what was from Phantom Brave, because the guy tailors his sound to his series rather than to the situation or any one style for all of his work.

And here, his work shines just as brightly as it ever has. Because Phantom Brave is one of the more somber and melancholic games he's worked on, rather than the usual frantic or chaotic melodies heard in Disgaeas 1-3, here we find that songs his are generally slower and themed based on context.  This might seem like it betrays my previous statements, but that speaks more to exactly how the characters and maps of the game are designed than anything of himself.  But rather than trying to convince you with words, I'll leave these here and let you be the judge.

This game is a real blast from my past! I remember playing this as a kid, and revisiting it years later, it still holds up really well. If you're here for the mix of dark and silly humor of the Disgaea series, you aren't going to find it here. Sure, the story has its funny moments, but for the most part it's a bit more on the serious side, and there's nothing wrong with that. Gameplay is the real reason to be here, though. Simple yet deep, Phantom Brave shines in inviting and personalized combat and team structure. Tons of different unit types to start and even more to unlock makes it easy to customize your team exactly the way that you want. The only equipment that you need to worry about is your weapon, but you can use everything from standard RPG Swords, Axes, and Spears to weirder options like Books, Scrolls, and Logs, to things that don't make sense like Trees, Trolley Cars, Weeds, and even other units! Tons of special attacks, lots of units specialization through the Fusion system, and easy access to almost every item make it easy to try and blend everything!

Combat doesn't take place on a grid; instead, your units have a circular distance count and can move anywhere on the map on their turn within that circle on their turn, making positioning more fluid, and position strategy is as precise as you want it to be. This is helped by your deployment system: Rather than having a whole army on the field, you have your main character, who summons units (Phantoms) into objects on the battlefield. After a few turns, they'll vanish, leaving room for another ally. So you can have as many allies on standby as you want to make, and pick the best for any situation.

This review doesn't truly do the depth of the game justice. But it's a great, deep, interesting game with a lot to offer to anyone who's a fan of the genre, and is looking for something fun, but different in terms of gameplay and customizeability.

Overall, as a unique entry in a landscape of very diverse turn based strategy games, Phantom Brave, to me, is special.  Story progression is entirely at your own pace, and offers a nice middle-ground difficulty between FFT 1.3 (Insane) and Disgaea 1.  The character class roster is huge and the random battlefield/dungeon generation is quirky and simply FUN.

I never would have thought a SRPG that centered around a single character who served as, essentially, your main menu, but was also required in every single major battle to fight alongside you could work- the concept itself is baffling at first- but Marona functions marvelously and switches things up a bit when similar titles rely on more standard planning and execution.

24752961.review:
Basically the definitive edition of Phantom Brave.  You've got arbitrary resolution support, instant switching of controller prompts/keyboard input, stability (not one crash or frame rate issue in the 40 hours I've played) and dual audio. 

Nippon Ichi SRPG's are mainly about finding enjoyment in making the numbers go up, and Phantom Brave probably scratches that itch best for me among their various SRPG's.  Unlike most SRPG's, you have a circular movement radius instead of grid-based movement.  This does cause issues with path-finding and targeting at times, but I like the feel of it and the freedom of movement it gives you.  It's somewhat similar to Valkyria Chronicles to give a point of reference.

Another aspect of PB that's a bit different is that you only have one "permanent" party member.  Marona is always on the field, but you summon your allies by confining them into various objects that increase/decrease certain stats and/or provide various types of protection/debuffs to your allies and enemies.  Summoned allies also have turn limits before being removed for the rest of fight, so you have to use some actual strategy at times when it comes to deploying your characters.  There's a real sense of asset management here if you play the game as a straight SRPG instead of the usual Nippon Ichi "power level your character/item until you're unstoppable" type of gameplay.  That said, you're free to power level to your heart's content if that's what you want to do, just making a point that PB has more strategic gameplay than you might expect.

The fusion system is your primary method of making the numbers go up and basically consists of mashing together two weapons and making the stats go up, along with the choice of adding new attacks to the weapon.  Fusion also works between characters and items and serves to provide very useful passive and active skills along with level cap increases.  There's more stuff to crazy stat increases like titles, failure fusions, etc, so your numbers go up hankering should be sated.  There's just something about the fusion system that appeals to me more than Disgaea's Item World stuff.

Phantom Brave leaves a lot to the player to figure out on their own, which might be a plus or negative depending on how you like your games.  There's an extended tutorial, but there's just too much to the gameplay to make it all digestible to a new player without overwhelming them.  This probably isn't the worst game to look up a beginner's guide to get some tips as you figure out how to play, especially if you aren't familiar with Nippon Ichi games.

In short, if you've played Phantom Brave in the past and are wondering if this is worth picking up again, then the answer is yes.  If you've never played a Nippon Ichi game before, be warned that all the systems and numbers might be a bit overwhelming at first, but if it clicks for you, you'll probably find yourself abandoning the main storyline to level your characters and weapons to the point where the AI can't even make a turn before you kill all of them.  If that doesn't appeal to you, it can also be played as more a "normal" SRPG, more so than Disgaea.  Recommend if you have any interest in SPRG's.

I have bought this game 4 times throughout its life and beaten the story multiple times. I don't need to play through the game again to prove that I love this game. But I can at least vouch for the port.

Phantom Brave isn't a perfect game or a masterpiece. It's not too hard to make the game easy, and the battle system, while different, isn't the deepest out there. That all said, the game is great and I highly recommend getting it if you're interested in a more serious SRPG compared to Disgaea.

The story centers around Marona and her guardian phantom: Ash. Much of the themes of the game revolve around prejudice and hope. Marona constantly gets burned by the people she helps, as their hate for what they see her as makes them treat her like dirt. Despite constant absue, Marona sticks to her parents' ideals they taught her in the hopes that she will one day be rewarded for her efforts. While it may be a bit irksome for some to have her be so optimistic, I do find it at least grounded by the fact that she's not inherently that pure. It is because of the support of Ash that she is able to hold on to these ideals; not because she's some pure person who can take all of this on her own. The secondary story, titled Another Marona, isn't quite as good as the main one. It does shed a bit of light on all the characters that one couldn't see in the main storyline, so it does offer something to those that enjoyed the characters and wanted to see more of them.

The meat and bones of the game is the gameplay. The battles play out in a turn based format on a girdless field. Characters have a set limit to their movement represented in DMs, but can move as many times as they want until the number of DMs is fully depleted. You can summon phantoms by confining them to various objects on the field, which grant certain bonuses. Phantoms have a set number of turns they can stay in battle, and when that depletes they leave the battle. Marona is the only character that stays on the field permanently, though there are ways to make some phantoms stick around as long. Attacks themselves have various ranges and AOE "shapes" in which they can effect the field. If you find the going to get rough, then you can pick up and throw allies to better position them, or even toss enemies out of bounds at the cost of slightly empowering the other enemies(though the last enemy standing is immune, if I recall). Any items that a phantom has been confined into has a chance of being "stolen", as well. 

There also a number of sub systems within the game. Titles can be bestowed upon any phantom or weapons you have, and each title has various stat bonuses. Some titles even contain special attack skills. You also enter random dungeons, fuse items and titles, and migrate any non-unique skills. Phantom Brave was ahead of its time.

In the PS2 era, it seemed like every RPG (or maybe all genres, actually) needed to go BIGGER. More dramatic, more epic, more serious. Nippon Ichi carved a niche for itself with Disgaea, a silly RPG that tried to be as un-serious as possible. It was more of an episodic anime, full of comedy and parodies. It was in the right place at the right time, and got a lot of attention. 

However, Phantom Brave took a riskier path. It was a "serious" story, yet instead of a fantasy epic, it aimed to be a gentle slice-of-life. You're not the center of the universe, but just a person in a tropical archipelago filled with strange and diverse characters. The story is about the orphan girl Marona, innocent and naive, watched over by her jaded phantom bodyguard, Ash. She tries to make her own way through the world, but her optimism clashes when it comes up against reality's cynicism and prejudices. This kind of character-driven story was very rare in games at the time, but is something that's become much more accepted in the past few years.

The gameplay system is also far ahead its time, though it may be still too advanced for us in 2016. There's a lot more freedom in this compared to the usual tactical RPG map battle. For one thing, you can free-roam instead of moving within a square grid. I like it better this way, but I have to admit it's a little clunkier just trying to move where you want. And there's more.... Confining phantoms to objects such as trees and rocks, which give different stat bonuses, yet they only last a limited number of turns in battle, so you have to pace yourself depending on the map. There's so much to keep track of. Yet there's no short-term pleasures like the team-attacks in Disgaea, it's all about the long-term strategy in each battle.

Same for outside of battle, you're given incredible freedom to customize and build your characters; even your ITEMS gain their own levels and new skills. You can even fuse characters/items together to break past the old limits of their potential.  It's not a regular RPG where you grind for a linear increase in power, but you use your brain and tinker with multiple systems to gain *exponential* boosts in power. The max level is 9999 for a good reason, not just to extend playtime. Yet this can be very overwhelming to a new player, as unlike Disgaea there's very little indication of what's effective RIGHT NOW, just hints of how godlike you can become later after you've "cracked the code." I don't recommend this at all for people who want a comfortable casual time, and to be honest it's too much even for me sometimes. I enjoy this kind of abstract stat manipulation stuff, yet this game was aimed at someone *even more hardcore* than me.

It's strange how such an accessible heartwarming story was fused with an inaccessible challenging game. It's definitely not for everyone (if you don't like complicated RPGs you might want to watch a LetsPlay instead). But it's bold and unique, and I love it anyway.

Phantom Brave é um jogo SRPG ou se preferir rpg tático, ao estilo disgaea, final fantasy, Xcom(+/-), no qual nosso personagem principal Marona tem poderes especial que a permitem ver, se comunicar e "confinar" espíritos e por conta desses poderes ela sofre muito preconceito (demonstrado várias vezes no game) também por contas desses poderes trabalha como "mercenário" ajudando os outros por recompensas, na esperança que um dia todo mundo  a reconheça e sejam seus amigos ou pelos menos parem de achar que ela é uma aberração.

Pobre Marona  :(

Analise
Phantom brave é um otimo jogo com sistemas inovadores, não limitidas a quadrados, uma fisica um tanto bizarra,  as vezes temos probemas com mouse por terem 2 cursores e quando muitos inimigos estão juntos, mas afim um jogo que não pode faltar para amantes de um bom e classico(até certo ponto) SRPG.

Como o jogo funciona?
 Temos uma ilha base na qual podemos:
-Recebe novas missões através de garrafas (com braços e pernas).
-Criar novos espíritos humanoides e de monstros (para ter novos é so derrotar os que aparecem) 
-Utiliza a classe dos espíritos (logo explico)
-Gerencia sua equipe.

Combate:
Você vai até sua caixa de correio e recebe missões, que vão desbloqueando novas ilhas, cada ilha vão conter fases após completar todas, você completa a missão.
Quando começa a batalha terá unicamente Marona no campo, a partir dela utilize o  comando "confine" para colocar espíritos nos objetos do cenário, como pedras, arvores, espadas, etc. Cada objeto fornecera aumentos ou diminuição nos status dos char além de poder serem usados como armas. Ex: Pedra aumenta força, hp, mas diminui inteligência e velocidade, então é mais recomendado para um guerreiro.
Cada espirito pode ficar apenas alguns turnos no campo, portanto pense bem antes de ir invocando todo mundo

Mana:
Conforme você luta seus personagens vão recebendo xp (convencional pra todos jogos) e mana que aqui é utilizado para armas (melhorar, ganhar novas skills e fusion) e char (fusion). A mana é individual de cada char ou item então não se preocupe em gastar.

Espíritos:
Diferentes de outros jogos onde você cria novos personagens apenas para te ajudar na batalha aqui os espíritos vendem itens, curam sua party (fora de batalha entre outros). Ex: você quer um ferreiro para melhorar suas armas, mesmo que não vá utiliza-lo em batalha, você tem que criar um ferreiro para poder melhorar suas armas, o mesmo vale para tudo o que precisar.

Armas:
Nunca vi armas serem tão bizarras e importantes num jogo quanto no Phantom Brave, vc pode usar praticamente tudo como arma uma pedra, uma arvore, um arbusto (a flora nunca foi tão importante), seus chars, até corpos de inimigos. Seus char n tem praticamente nenhuma habilidade, e as armas são como personagens ganham xp, mana evoluem, ganham novas habilidades (através do ferreiro).

Ferreiros:
Para ter novas habilidades ou aumentar os level das armas é necessário ter um ferreiro, que voce consegue nos primeiros mapas do jogo, para ter novas habilidades ou melhorar é necessário apenas mana, só cuidado para ver se terá algum personagem que consegue usar aquela habilidade.
Mana é individual de cada char e item então pode aproveitar

Skil:
Primeiramente, você não tem uma barra de mana que é usado para skill, tem pontos em 7 classes de habilidades e cada char tem um nivel de aptidão em cada uma, que vão de F até S e para utilizar as skill você precisa dos pontos necessários naquela habilidade especifica. Ex: você tem um guerreiro com uma espada, a espada tem as habilidades: angle slash que precisa de 0 pontos para ser utilizada, berseker que precisa de 3 pontos, e seu char tem apenas 4 pontos, então ele pode utilizar quantas vezes quiser angle slash, mas apenas 1 vez berseker, pois serão gastos 3 pontos.
Para aumentar o limite de pontos existem 2 maneiras, 1ª utilizar skill daquela classe e 2° fusão entre chars.

Fusion:
Já que os chars tem poucas habilidades o jeito é fundir, unir personagens ou objetos, quando unimos char aos objetos poderemos passar as habilidades das armas pra eles, caso tenham mana suficiente pra isso, no caso de unimos char + char eles podem ganhar suas habilidades e seus skills points nas categorias desde que estes sejam maiores do que o primeiro. Ex: Marona + Arvore com a skill thorns = Marona com skill thorns. Quanto maior classe naquele tipo de habilidade menor o custo (F custo aumentado, S custo diminuído)
Fusão char + char, char + item e item + item, aumentam o level max e podem aumentar ou diminuir stats dos seus chars.
Não são passadas skills que precisam de 0 sp.

Obrigado por lerem.

[h1]Story:[/h1]

Phantom Brave follows the story of a young girl named Marona whose family and friend were killed by a monster several years ago. The friend however managed to survive with the help of her father's miracle, but wasn't fully revived, turning him into a Phantom, who are beings not exactly alive or dead. [h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

The gameplay of the game might be surprising to newcomers as they it doesn't make use of the grid system. Instead, you can freely move across the map, having a set distance you can move per turn. Of course, objects can obstruct your movement, so the circle shown during gameplay is not accurate at all. Another mechanic this game has is the "Turn" system. Each phantom can be summoned by Marona from an item ([spoiler]Carona can be summoned and summon as well[/spoiler]), in a big circle around her, unobstructed by height or objects. Bare in mind that there are limits in summoning phantoms, as there can only be a certain amount of Phantoms in the map at any time (items also count as Phantoms). As soon as one Phantom goes home, you can summon another Phantom to take its place.

In battle, much like Disgaea where you can pick up each other; you can pick up items, players or dead bodies (to equip them) and throw them. This allows for strategic summoning (an example) where Marona throws the item she is equipping and then immediately summons a Phantom there, for long distance action.

Each item/character gives stats to the player equipping it/him/her. Only items however can be used in fusion to increase their stats, their level caps and add new skills (characters can be used in fusion, but cannot gain stats this way, only increase their level cap and add new skills). This allows for some really lame looking weapons to be really overpowered. Generally, unless you are looking for a no-weapon playthrough of the game, this will be the main way of strengthening your characters (leveling up is another way of course, but it's much easier to use fusion instead of grinding levels).

In replacement of the item world we all know and love from Disgaea, the game has a random dungeon system, where dungeons are generated randomly by a DungeonMonk (yeah... no spaces). These can vary in level (linked to the DungeonMonk's level), in title name, floor number, size of the map, the number of enemies in the map, the type of enemies in the map, the ground type, the items that are spawned in the map and item restrictions.

Although you can do this, it isn't really needed, as grinding to get this kind of title is long and tedious. You don't even have to do this to finish all the extra maps.

Despite all these differences, I still think that it has that Disgaea feel to it. I also really feel that it's very strategic in the sense that you have to know when to summon Phantoms and the fact you can throw items around and then summon Phantoms there. For gameplay, I'd say this game is very solid and unique.

[b]TL;DR: Lots of mechanics. Good game. Play it.[/b]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

With all that said, I think the game is great and will definitely recommend it for people to play. If you're worried about the quality of the port, I will just say that this port is much better and much less buggy.

NIS is known for their strategy games, and each one has a special charm, but Phantom Brave will always be my favroite NIS title, and my favorite SRPG. 

The game is very unique in the way it condutcs itself. On the surface, it seems like its just a typical turn based strategy game, but Phantom Brave puts out two unique twists to the genre:

1). you can freely move about the map, there are no tiles. If you have the movement stat, you can go pretty much anywhere

2). you start each battle with one character. You summon units, called "phantoms" by channeling their spirit into objects. Each unit you summon also has a set amount of turns they can be used before they dissapear for the remainder of the battle.

These two aspects of the game make it such a unique and fun experience, and it defenitely makes you think about each battle.  It also forces the player to train other units and establish an army, because if you have 1 OP unit, you cannot have him go around and kill everything, you need to utlize other characters and classes, otherwise you will run out of characters and will most likely get a game over. 

As for the music, there are some tracks that are truly memorable (the title screen for instance), and there are tracks that are just "ok" but nothing that will strain your ears. 

The story isn't too much to write home about in my opinion. It's not a waste of time, and it does well to complement the gameplay, but it's not the best part of the game. 

If you are a fan of NIS, SRPGS, or RPGs in general and want something truly unique, then this game is for you.

This is also the defenitive version of the game. All of the content from the WII and PSP releases are in this package.
